awd_titl_txt: Geological and Paleoanthropological Data Harmonization Workshop
awd_abstract_narration:
Research findings from one project or site are usually more informative about underlying phenomena when they can be compared with data from other relevant research sites. To be meaningful, such comparisons may require shared vocabulary, methods, and data formats, in addition to collaboration across research groups. This field-based workshop will bring together geologists and paleoanthropologists to discuss best practices and protocols for comparing data across research sites, using several Pliocene and early Pleistocene hominin fossil locations in the Awash basin of Ethiopia. The workshop will also generate new research questions for future collaborative projects that span beyond individual project boundaries. Participants will include graduate students, early career scientists, international scholars, and groups underrepresented in STEM disciplines. A component of this workshop will contribute to the NSF-supported PaleoCore project by helping to synthesize and standardize geological mapping data and creating a template that can be used by any other geological project. This award is co-funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering.

A major impediment to the study of human origins and evolution has been that field studies are often conducted within the bounds of spatially restricted project areas. These project area boundaries are rarely based on broader ecological or geological constraints, and these limitations impede the formulation of overarching research questions that are critical for understanding hominin evolution and its context over larger scales of time and space. For geologists, conducting inter- and intraregional comparisons can be challenging as they do not always have direct knowledge of information from adjacent research project areas boundaries across which outcrops are contiguous. As a result, researchers have not effectively and comprehensively addressed broader regional-scale research questions. This workshop reflects the idea that substantial progress could be made in understanding the geological context of human evolution through better communication, collaborative work, and transparent data sharing. No one location/research project in the lower Awash River valley preserves a complete and continuous sequence of Pliocene and early Pleistocene sediments. When combined, however, they encompass an impressive temporal and spatial coverage of early hominin habitats within a complex rifting environment. There is tremendous potential to use the combined record from these project areas to evaluate how rifting has evolved and to explore the interplay between climate, tectonics, hominin evolution, and paleoecology in the Afar. The workshop will also result in a report that discusses best practices for planning and conducting research across separate but related research sites.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the broad geological context of hominin evolution in the East African Rift is fundamental to paleoanthropological research but requires investigations that transcend formal permit boundaries and geographic foci. While relatively small study areas are practical for regulatory or logistical reasons and sufficient for some paleontological or archaeological studies, these project boundaries are rarely based on broader paleoecological or geological research questions. For this reason, geologists and paleontologists conducted a field workshop in the Afar region of Ethiopia for 2 weeks in January 2019 with site visits to the paleoanthropological project areas of Hadar, Dikika, Woranso-Mille, Ledi-Geraru, and Mille-Logya. Participants included 15 scientists from American/European institutions and 5 scientists from three different Ethiopian institutions. This visit included discussions of outstanding geological questions about the individual project areas and the projects they share boundaries with, and more importantly, questions that could only be addressed though comparisons with neighboring projects or regional syntheses. 

Individual research projects in the lower Awash valley region of Ethiopia include varying degrees of overlapping and separate temporal windows into Plio-Pleistocene hominin evolution. In many cases, the same continuous geologic units are exposed in multiple research project areas but are under study by different nonoverlapping teams of geologists. No one location/research project area preserves a complete and continuous sequence of Pliocene and early Pleistocene sedimentary and volcanic rocks. However, when combined, they encompass an impressive temporal and spatial coverage of early hominin habitats within a complex rift environment. The combined record from these project areas can be used to evaluate how rifting has evolved and to explore the complex interplay among climate, tectonics, evolution, and ecology in the Afar.  We recognize that the whole is greater than the sum of its parts and that geological research questions pertaining to early hominin paleoenvironments can only be answered by multi-project interdisciplinary integration and cooperation. 

Although some degree of collaboration existed between geologists working at different sites in the lower Awash valley this collaboration has been limited and informal. We realized during this field workshop that the existing model of geological research in the Afar region has led to missed opportunities for collaboration and stunted our ability to develop synthetic views of the depositional/tectonic system as a whole. It demonstrated that our ultimate research goals can only be achieved by working together to not only share data, but collaboratively investigate exposures across site boundaries. Based on our brief experience, having geologists with different perspectives (both regional and in terms of specialty) collaborate and draw on group experience enables a semantic integration and provides the opportunity to address issues of regional importance in the field with access to primary data that will likely prove invaluable. 

An overarching question developed from this workshop asks: What are the relative roles and interaction of climate modulation, tectonic deformation, and volcanic input on geological, landscape, and faunal evolution? This was broken down into various themes (e.g., hydrology, tectonics/volcanism, and vegetation/climate evolution) that can be used to establish paleoecological overlays on an evolving geological framework. Workshop participants are now actively working on rethinking how our science can address fundamental cross-cutting questions about hydrology, sedimentation, tectonics, volcanism, ecology, and evolution in a rift setting. We aim to do this with an ethos of open data and open access wherever possible, breaking traditional barriers to research collaboration, while respecting existing boundaries of projects. Ideas for collaborative research not only focus on ambitious large-scale regional projects, but also those that could advance our objectives at a variety of scales. This includes proposals ranging from using existing data sets and geological samples, to smaller, more targeted cross-project efforts to test specific hypotheses. We intend to capitalize on our current momentum to further novel and transformative research in the lower Awash valley, while also expanding training of Ethiopian scientists and better communication with local communities and stakeholders. Geological research at the lower Awash valley paleoanthropological sites traditionally focused on providing context for hominin evolution. Our future endeavors will continue to provide this context, while also contributing to larger synthetic models of landscape evolution.
